metadata.title: Recent Advances of Ternary Layered Cu2MX4 (M = Mo, W; X = S, Se) Nanomaterials for Photocatalysis

sections.text:
Photocatalysis www.solar-rrl.com
REVIEW ARTICLE
Recent Advances of Ternary Layered Cu2MX4 (M¼Mo, W; X¼ S, Se) Nanomaterials for Photocatalysis
Yunxiang Lin, Shuangming Chen,* Ke Zhang, and Li Song*
Photocatalytic technologies, based on efficient light absorption and conversion, have emerged as a viable solution to overcome the problems related to energy and the environment. Development of new cost-effective materials coupled with the green synthesis routes in order to replace the noble metalbased catalysts is critical to overcoming this challenge. In this review, a brief summary of the recent progress in ternary layered Cu2MX4 (M¼Mo, W; X¼ S, Se) nanomaterials and their photocatalytic performance is presented. First, the structural configurations with different phases and crystallinity are described, as well as various experimental synthesis methods of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials. Thereafter, the effect of morphology modulation, facet selection, and multicomponent hybridization on the catalytic activity of Cu2MX4 is elucidated. In addition, a proposal for highly-efficient Cu2MX4 photocatalysts is presented via rational designing strategies for realizing their specific applications in the fields of photodegradating organic pollutants, water splitting, and other photocatalytic reactions. Finally, the existing research challenges related to ternary Cu2MX4 layers along with future prospects are discussed in detail.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the growing industrialization and urbanization, energy and environmental problems have become a serious threat.[1–5] The rapid depletion of fossil fuels (coal, natural gas, and petroleum oil) calls for the development of renewable energies based on sufficient energy sources with sustainable supply at large scale.[6–11] In addition, wasted water from printing and dyeing industry containing high-toxic organic dye is hard to be decomposed by traditional physical, chemical, or biological method.[12,13] Exploring cost-effective, green technologies to solve energy and environmental problems have become a hot topic with a worldwide attention.[14–16] Increasing efforts have been made to develop new technologies based on a highly efficient conversion of solar energy, such as photocatalytic water splitting and photodegradation of organic pollutant.[17–23]

Generally, the photocatalytic process undergoes three main steps: First, the photo-induced electrons migrate from the valance band (VB) to conduction band (CB) of photocatalysts under the light irradiation, leaving behind an equal amount of holes at the original location below the valance band maximum (VBM). Then, the electrons and holes are transferred to the surface of photocatalysts. Finally, the photocatalytic process occurs with the dye degradation or water molecules splitting on the surface of photocatalysts.[24–26] So far, modifying traditional photocatalysts (e.g., TiO2
[27,28], CdS,[29,30] and BiWO6
[31]) for enhanced activity or developing new type of photocatalysts (e.g., sulfides[29], oxides,[32] and nitrides[33]) have been regarded as two competitive strategies to meet the demand for solving energy and environmental problems.Amongvariousnewmaterials, layered Cu2MX4 (M¼Mo,W;X¼S,Se),which is an important ternary transition metal chalcogenide (TTMC), has attracted much atten-
tion due to the outstanding propertieswith adjustable component, variable structure, diversified morphology, and unique electronic structure. Given that Cu2MX4 shows suitable band gap structure and elemental abundance in nature, it has been widely studied in photocatalytic degradation and water splitting. Furthermore, its flexible morphological properties can not only be readily adjusted by regulating the synthesis conditions, but also through combining with other components, which directly modulates the light response of the photocatalytic system.
During the past few years, several principles and strategies have been developed for regulating the morphological and structural characteristics of ternary Cu2MX4 in the following aspects: 1) engineering different synthetic strategies to achieve various crystalline Cu2MX4 nanomaterials; 2) modulating the morphology of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials by adjusting the synthetic routes; 3) precise tuning of the exposed facet for improved light-response; 4) enhancing the photocatalytic system by compound Cu2MX4 with other materials. In this brief review, we are going to summarize recent progresses in tailoring ternary Cu2MX4 nanomaterials from the aspects of structure and facet modulation, controllable synthesis, and hybridization toward high-efficiency photocatalytic performance for organic matter degradation and hydrogen evolution. The existing challenges and possible solutions are discussed to serve as a guideline for rational design and potential applications of ternary Cu2MX4 based photocatalysts.

sections.heading: 2. Structural Configuration and Characterization of Layered Cu2MX4
sections.text:
The crystal structure of Cu2MX4 materials was integrally unraveled by Gan et al.[34] Generally, Cu2MX4 nanomaterials can exist in two phases with space group P 42m and I 42m, respectively. The Cu2MX4 commonly shows tetragonal structure that are different from other typical layered materials with a hexagonal structure (e.g., graphene, g-boron nitride, transition metal chalcogenides). The central atomM is connected with four X atoms by covalent bond in both of P-phase and I-phase. Besides, the formed MX4 tetrahedra and CuX4 tetrahedra are separated by sharing the edge X atoms. Thus, both of the P-phase and I-phase Cu2MX4 have the same layered structure.
[35] The main difference between these two phases is the stacking configuration between layers, themonolayers are stacked to each other by AAA arrangement in P-phase and ABA arrangement in I-phase. As shown in Figure 1A,B, the Cu and M atoms are alternately located in the I-phase structure while the M atoms are located as separate columns by the side of alternate Cu and M atoms in the case of P-phase. Besides, the X atoms are located on the edge of the metal atomic plane versus c-axis as can be seen through the side view of layer Cu2MX4 crystals. The monolayers express a sandwiched structure in which the metal atoms are sandwiched by X atoms and show the thickness of 2.60–2.90 Å, these layers are connected to each other through Van Der Waals forces in bulk materials. The parameters (e.g., thickness of monolayer, bond length, and lattice constant) of the different type of Cu2MX4 materials are mainly decided by the element M and X. The lattice constant and thickness of monolayer is decreases while changing from W to Mo with a common X and increases while replacing S to Se with common metal. In addition, the bond length of Cu-S and Cu-M in Cu2WS4 is larger than that of Cu2MoS4.
Most of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials are indirect semiconductors with a calculated band gap range from 1.26 to 2.26 eV.[34] Normally, the electrons gather at the M atoms while the holes are accumulated at the Cu and X atoms in ternary Cu2MX4. The VBM can be attributed to the Cu and X atoms while the conduction band minimum (CBM) is attributed to M atoms. Comparing the band gap of two phases, the I-phase often shows a larger band gap than P-phase. Moreover, as illustrated in Figure 1E, the band gap value of Cu2MX4 decreases while replacing S to Se for the same M atom while increases upon replacing Mo to W for the same X atom. Due to the acute unstablility of [MoSe]2þ, the theoretical computation of Cu2MoSe2 was not been considered here.
[34] According to the band gap requirement of photocatalystic reaction, Cu2MoS4 is suitable for full water splitting while Cu2WS4 often applies to water reduction for hydrogen evolution.
On the other side, with the rapid advancement of scientific research, many advanced technologies have been used for characterizing the structural detail of functional materials, such as the X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman, scanning electron microscope (SEM), transmission electron microscope (TEM), and other related technologies. Herein, synchrotron-based X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) technologies are being focused on owing to the fact that it can pinpoint the local geometric structure and valence state
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (2
information of the central atoms.[36,37] The X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra can be attributed to two main part: the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). The XANES spectrum is often relevant to the structural symmetry of the bulk materials and electronic states of the absorption atoms while the EXAFS spectrum often reveals the chemical environment (e.g., coordination number, bond length).[38,39] Our group recently explicated the chemical environment of Cu and Mo atoms of Cu2MoS4 nanosheet by using XAS measurement.
[35,40] The Fourier transformed EXAFS (FT-EXAFS) spectrum for Cu Kedge of Cu2MoS4 is shown in Figure 1C,D, the first and second shell bonding exhibits two main peaks located at 1.8 and 2.3 Å in the R range from 1.5 to 3 Å, corresponding to the Cu-S and CuMo bond, respectively. Two peaks are located at 1.8 and 2.3 Å in the Mo K-edge FT-EXAFS, corresponding to the Mo-S bond and Mo-Cu bond. The detailed structural parameters of the Cu2MoS4 have also been identified by fitting the FT-EXAFS spectra using

Thus, more details about the electronic states and the geometrical structure of Cu2MX4materials might possibly be analyzed by XAS or other advanced technologies in the future.

sections.heading: 3. Controllable Synthesis of Ternary Cu2MX4
sections.text:
Up to now, various type of layered materials have been synthesised through different routes, such as chemical vapor transportation (CVT),[41–43] chemical vapor deposition (CVD),[44– 46] wet-chemical methods,[47] and other physical or chemical methods. The annual publications about Cu2MX4 nanomaterials have been briefly concluded in a histogram (Figure 1F), It can be seen that the research work based on Cu2MX4 nanomaterials has
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (3
got an enormous increase in preceding three years as Cu2MX4 is relatively a new material type for photocatalyst. In this part, we primarily focused on the various synthetic routes among these works, especially from the aspects of synthetic method and the growthmechanism. As is known to all, the synthetic strategy can directly influence the parameters of the catalysts (e.g., morphology,[48,49] particle size,[50] surface defect,[51] and exposed crystal facet[52]). Similar to the synthesis route of traditional transition metal sulfide, the Cu2MX4 can be obtained by the reaction of the M source, Cu source and X source together or through the reaction of Cu source with [MX4]
2 ion. Besides, Cu2MX4 has similar layered structure to MX2 and the required energy for liquid-phase exfoliation of Cu2MX4 is close to graphene and MS2, indicating that it is possible to obtain Cu2MX4 monolayer.
[34] However, due to the more ionic bond in the ternary structure, it is still a challenge to obtain monolayer Cu2MX4 in experimentally. In Table 1, we have briefly

summarized the synthesis methods and the obtained morphologies of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials with their photocatalytic performance.

sections.heading: 3.1. Reflux Precipitation Method
sections.text:
The layered P-phase Cu2WS4 was firstly synthesized through reflux precipitation method by Pruss et al., demonstrating a crystalline Cu2MX4 nanostructure.
[53] In the preparation, [Cu(CH3CN)4]BF4 and (NH4)WS4 were mixed in a molar ratio of 2:1 and reaction was allowed to proceed at 135 C under inert atmosphere in equivalent N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and butyronitrile mixed solvent. The WS4
2 replaced the fairly unstable CH3CN ligands. After refluxing for 24h, the bright orange precipitate were formed. It was followed by washing with water and ethanol for several times and overnight drying under vacuum to obtain the final product of Cu2WS4. Thereafter, the structure of Cu2WS4 nanocrystal was confirmed by combining XRD and calculated profiles. Tran et al., replaced the butyronitrile by acetonitride (MeCN) to successfully synthesize the P-phase Cu2MoS4 with improved crystallinity.
[54] In order to further enhance the performance, they compounded the Cu2MoS4 nanoparticles with 10% graphene oxide (GO) through adding GO into the DMF and acetonitrile mixed solution before reflux.[5]
Recently, selenium (Se) doped Cu2MoS4 nanomaterials were successfully synthesized through themodified refluxprecipitation method by Lee et al. as shown in Figure 2A.[55] For synthesis, the [Cu (MeCN)](BF4)], (NH4)[MoS4], anddiphenyl diselenide (DPDS) werefirstly dissolved in acetonitrile solution; then the solutionwas refluxed in the DMF/MeCNmixed solvent under inert condition; Finally, the dark-vine Se doped Cu2MoS4 was obtained after cleaning and drying. Notbaly, theDPDSwas used as the Se source for Se-doped Cu2MoS4. This study provides a facile way to further selectively dope hetro-atoms into Cu2MoS4 layers.

sections.heading: 3.2. Hot-Injection Method
sections.text:
The hot-injection method was firstly used to synthesize CdX (X¼S, Se, Te) semiconductor nanocrystallites by using organometallic Cd and S (or Se, Te) as the precursors, reacting
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (4
in highly boiled trioctylphosphine oxide (TOPO) solvent.[56] Unlike the previous wet-chemical synthetic method, the hotinjection method uses the organometallic precursor in apolar coordinating alkyl solution instead of the metallic salt precursor in water or another polar solvent, which offers a slow growth process for the defect-free nanocrystals.[57] In addition, the products obtained from hot-injection method show a high degree of monodispersity because of the equilibrium between the precursors and newly formed molecular units.
In order to reduce the reaction time and required ambient pressure, colloidal Cu2WS4 nanocrystals had been synthesized through hot-injection method with a rapid reaction time of 30min by Patir et al.[58] During preparation, CuCl2 2H2O and WCl4 were adopted as the starting materials while the oleylamine (OLA) was chosen as the capping agent. Then, the mixed solution containing Cu and W source was stirred in a three-necked flask under an inert atmosphere. After that, OLA solution containing S fine powder was added into the flask followed by rapid heating to a higher temperature with continuous stirring for the growth of Cu2WS4 nanocrystals. Before oleic acid was added into the black solution, the Cu2WS4 nanocubes were obtained through washing several times by the toluene and ethanol mixed solution. Besides, when the S powder was replaced by Se, Cu2WSe4 layeres were formed (Figure 2B).[59] Although Cu2WS4 and Cu2WSe4 have been synthesized successfully through hot-injection method, a challenge still remains to selectively prepare the Cu2MoS4 or Cu2MoSe4.

sections.heading: 3.3. Hydro/Solvo-Thermal Method
sections.text:
As one of the most popular synthesis methods of nanomaterials, hydro/solvo-thermal method has been widely adopted for the regulating of electronic characteristics or other properties. Typically, the precursors are well dispersed into the solvent (e.g., water or other solution) and sealed in a Teflon-lined autoclave before heating to the intended temperature. It has been estimated that the inner pressure of autoclave is an extreme chemical condition for heterogeneous chemical reaction. Thus, the precursors can fully react under the supercritical condition, resulting in various nanocrystals. Furthermore, the phase,

For examples, Cu2WS4 layers were synthesized by solvo-thermal method by Evans et al.[60] The main phase of Cu2WS4 was changed from P-phase (at 135 C) to I-phase (at 250 C) with the increased temperature. Additionally, the color of the synthesizedmaterial was changed from orange to brown when the temperature was elevated above 220 C. Furthermore, Cu2WSe4, Cu2MoS4, Cu2MoSe4, and Cu2WSxSe4-x were also successfully synthesized by changing the precursor or controlling the reaction conditions. (PPh4)2WSe4 was selected as the [WSe4]
2 ion donor for the synthesizing of Cu2WSe4. Temperature below 160 C yeilded pure P-phase while I-phase Cu2WSe4 was selectively obtained upon exceeding the temperature above 220 C.[61] Besides, both
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (5
of the P- and I-phase Cu2WSe4 can be observed when the temperature between 160 and 220 C. In addition, a new phase marked as PPh4Cu2WSe4 was witnessed during the temperature range of 185–190 C. Due to the similar synthesis routes of Cu2WS4 and Cu2WSe4, the mixed anion materials of Cu2WSxSe4-x were prepared by reacting (Cu[MeCN]4BF4) with (NH4)2WS4 and (PPh4)2WSe4 mixture. As for Cu2MoS4, the required temperature is only 110–150 C to form the crystalline Cu2MoS4 nanomaterials because the (MoS4)
2 ion is unstable when the temperature surpasses 150 C. Despite the successful synthesis of several Cu2MX4, synthesis of Cu2MoSe4 layers is still a challenging, probably because of the low stability of (MoSe4)
2 ion. Recently, Guo et al. have successfully synthesized the Cu2MoS4 and Cu2WS4 by using CuCl, (NH4)2MoS4, Na2WO4 2H2O, and thioacetamide (TAA) as the precursors in ammonia
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimof 13)
solution under various temperature.[62,63] Our group reported that Cu2MoS4 could also be controllablly synthesized by using Cu2O template, reacting with (NH4)2MoS4 or Na2WO4 2H2O and TAA. By tuning Cu2O templates, sphereshaped,[64] belt-shaped,[65] or cube-shaped[66] Cu2MoS4 nanomaterials have been selectively synthesized via solvo-thermal method. The growth mechanism of CuMoS4 was shown in Figure 2C,D. In principle, Cu2MoS4 hollow spheres were obtained after the Cu2O spheres were etched by [MoS4]
2 ion because of the Kirkendall effect. Furthermore, the Cu2MoS4 intermediates break into small pieces and these small pieces assemble and rearrange themselves to form CuMoS4 nanosheet (Figure 2C). In addition, these small pieces can be oriented on the surface of Cu2O, followed by the growth of crystals in preferred direction (Figure 2D).

sections.heading: 3.4. Other Available Methods
sections.text: Although various chemical methods have been developed for the selective synthesis of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials with controllable properties, some physicalmethods are still showing superiority in the fabrication of nanomaterials. Among them, chemical vapor deposition (CVD),[67,68] chemical vapor transportation (CVT),[69] or solid-phase method have been widely used to obtain the nondefective, large-scale nanomaterials, or other single crystals. Most recently, the Cu2MoS4 nanoparticles synthesized by solid-phase method were reported by Wang et al.[70] For the synthsis, CuCl, (NH4)6Mo7O24, and Na2S 9H2O were mixed by grinding for 20min before annealing at 200 C under vacuum for 3 h. The brown-red P-phase Cu2MoS4 nanoparticles were obtained after washing the products several times and drying under vacuum. However, due to the uncontrollable growth process during the solid-phase synthesizing process, themorphology of theCu2MoS4 nanoparticles was inhomogeneous. Thus, developing suitable physical method for the controllable synthesis of Cu2MX4 single crystals with uniform morphologies or other non-defect nanomaterials may be of great significance for future.

sections.heading: 4.1. Morphology Modulation
sections.text:
Owing to the suitable band gap and unique electronic structure, layered Cu2MX4 nanomaterials have been widely utilized for the photo-induced degradation of organic dyestuff and water splitting.[34] Actually, different morphologies of catalysts with unique physical characteristics may show distinct performance during the catalytic process.[71–74] Various morphologies of layered Cu2MX4 nanomaterials have been reported, including nanosheets,[35] nanoparticle,[5,61] nanobelt,[65] sphere,[64] and nanotube.[40,75] Thus, suitably regulating the morphology of Cu2MX4 with varied structural characteristics may result in different performance toward specific photocatalytic reactions.
For example, for the first time, Cu2MoS4 was experimentally applied as the photocatalyst to realize the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution from water splitting by Guo et al.[63] Comparatively, the pyramidal particulate Cu2MoS4 showed the
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (6
best photocatalytic hydrogen evolution activity (0.175mmol g 1 h 1), which is much better than that of flake-shape Cu2MoS4 and the intermediate products with both morphologies. As shown in Figure 3A, the UV-response results demonstrated that the pyramidal particulate Cu2MoS4 showed the strongest absorption band at 705 nm in the visible light region while the absorption of other samples is negligible, indicating that the samples synthesized at 160 C and higher temperature have metallic properties. The strong absorption can be subsequently attributed to the charge transfer from impurity level to conduction band in pyramidal particulate Cu2MoS4. Similarly, the microstructure analysis of Cu2WS4 crystal under different reaction temperatures showed that the sample crystallinity increased with the increased reaction temperature.[62] However, when the temperature reached up to 220 C or a higher, the crystal would decompose and collapse. As shown in Figure 3B, the Cu2WS4 crystal synthesized under 200 C for 72 h not only showed a uniform morphology, but also exhibited the highest activity of photocatalytic hydrogen evolution.
Recently, our group systematically studied the morphologies and photocatalytic performance of Cu2MoS4 nanomaterials under different synthesis conditions through template method based on the Kirkendall effect. First, Cu2MoS4 nanosheets were designed and synthesized by using ethylene glycol (EG) as a solvent, through the reaction of Cu2O nanosphere with Na2MoO4 2H2O and TAA under various temperature for 24 h.[35] The photocatalytic performance of Cu2MoS4 nanosheets was tested for the degradation of organic pollutant methylene orange (MO) under visible-light. As demonstrated, the 100mL MO solution with a concentration of 15mgL 1 can be fully degraded after illuminating for 120min, implying its application for the photocatalytic degradation of organic pollutant. Furthermore, the cube-like Cu2MoS4, with a band gap of 1.78 eV and strong absorption in the visible region, was successfully synthesized by simply adjusting the reaction parameters of nanosheet to a temperature of 160 C for 12 h.[66] The Photocatalytic degradation ability of Cu2MoS4 nanocubes was a little bittle lower than nanosheets probably due to exposure of more active sites in sheet-like morphology.
As follows, the Cu2MoS4 hollow spheres, [64] nanobelts,[65] and nanotubes[40] were controllably synthesized for further comparison. As shown in Figure 3C,D, the Cu2MoS4 hollow spheres were firstly obtained by reacting Cu2O and (NH4)2MoS4 in DI water at 180 C for 24 h. The Cu2MoS4 hollow spheres exhibited good photo-response when compounded to reduced GO (rGO). The photocurrent of Cu2MoS4@rGO (10.5mA cm 2) is almost five times more than that of pure Cu2MoS4 (2.0mA cm 2) (Figure 3E), suggesting a fast charge separation process in the composite structure, resulting in a largely enhanced photocatalytic ability. As exhibited in Figure 3F, the dye with a concentration of 15mg L 1 can be degraded completely within 20min for the Cu2MoS4 nanobelts amount of 50mg with a good stability, which is much better than that of nanosheets and hollow spheres@rGO hybrids. The Cu2MoS4 nanotube (Figure 3G) with a band gap of 1.53 eV can be selectively synthesized by reaction 40mg of Cu2O and 216mg of (NH4)2MoS4 under 120 C for 3 h by hydrothermal method. It took only 8min for the 50mg of Cu2MoS4 nanotube to fully degrade the MO

nanomaterials lead to various photo-response properties. Regulating the morphologies of photocatalysts can not only change the crystal field environment, binding energy of surface atoms, but also results in the modification of the band structure and exposed active sites of materials. Obviously, the
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimof 13)
photocatalytic performance is mainly influenced by the VBM and CBM position of photocatalysts, which is critical to the photocatalytic activity of photocatalysts.[76,77] As discussed earlier, the nanosheets, nanoparticles, nanobelts, and nanotubes structures of Cu2MX4 have expressed various activities toward hydrogen evolution and photodegradation. However, the studies to unravel the origin of different performance out of different morphologies are still scarce. For example, the Cu2MoS4 nanotubes had shown a competitive performance for photodegradation and hydrogen evolution, which might be due to the exposure of high-energy facet and the more exposed active sites enabling an enhanced chemical adsorption and desorption of intermediates and activation of water. Thus, further attention should be paid on boosting the adaptable band structures, highly-efficient charge separations and enhanced catalytic efficiency of active facet and sites.

sections.heading: 4.2. Facet Engineering
sections.text:
Generally, different facets with various electronic structural characteristics of nanocrystals often show distinguishable reactions selectively for a particular photocatalysts. For example, the {011} facet is much more thermostable and active than other facet of anatase TiO2 nanocrystals, which has been verified by both theoretical and experimental methods.[78–80] It was found that the WO3 with more high-energy {001} facet can show an obvious higher photocatalytic performance than those which do not expose more high-energy facet.[81,82] Similar evidences have also been confirmed on the {010} and {100} facets of BiVO4 nanocrystals, [83] and {001} facet of BiOBr.[84] Thus, fabricating uniform and high purity nanocrystals with more exposed highlyactivity facet is of great significance for the further photocatalytic applications.
The influence of facet on the Cu2MX4 nanocrystals by fabricating the decahedral Cu2WS4 single crystal with exposed {001} and {101} facet was reported by Guo et al.[52] A large coverage of {001} facet can be obtained by adding PVP into the standard reaction while a small coverage of {001} facet can be achieved by reducing the water and ethanol amount among the solvent (Figure 4A). Furthermore, photo-induced oxidation reaction sites have been disclosed through in situ observation of the photo-induced etching on different facet of Cu2WS4 single crystals. For Pt and Ru, the clusters were mostly deposited on the {001} facet of the decahedral Cu2WS4 under light irradiation, however, they were uniformly deposited on both {001} and {101} facet of decahedral Cu2WS4 without light irradiation (the clusters are reduced by ascorbic acid), indicating the facet selectivity of these noble metals during the adsorption/desorption process under light irradiation. Unlike the morphology differences on the photocatalytic performance, the adjustment of {001} and {101} facet ratio shows an exceedingly important role toward hydrogen evolution reaction. As shown in Figure 4B, with an increased ratio of facet amount {001}/{101}, the photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate increased visibly and showed enhanced photocatalytic performance when decorating with Pt clusters. Besides, the sample with the highest {001}/{101} ratio of 8.8 has shown the highest hydrogen evolution ratio of 138.2mmol h 1, which is nearly three times more than that of the smallest {001}
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (8
decahedra. Thus, the facet effect is believed to play amore crucial role in photocatalytic performance than surface area or crystal size effect.
The influence of {010} facet on the photocatalytic performance toward Cu2MoS4 nanotube has also been studied by combining experimental and theoretical methods.[40] The exposure of {010} facet was demonstrated by TEM, HAADF, and SAED analysis by using {010} facet exposed Cu2MoS4 nanosheet as the contrast sample (Figure 4C). The ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy valence-band spectra of nanotube and nanosheet manifests that the VBM of nanotubes is 0.19 eV deeper than that of nanosheets, which leads to a higher oxidation energy of the photo-induced holes. Density of states (DOS) curves of {010} and {001} facets (Figure 4D) depict that the VBM for {010} facet is higher than that of {001} facet, which not only leads to the enhanced adsorption of cationic dye molecules, but is also beneficial for the generation of photo-induced Hþ to H2. Besides, the {010} facet exposed Cu2MoS4 nanotubes expressed a high efficiency of photocatalytic degradation of MO and hydrogen evolution compared to that of {001} facet exposed Cu2MoS4 nanosheets. The Cu2MoS4 nanotubes could fully degrade the MO solution with a concentration of 15mgL 1 in 8min and split the water with a hydrogen evolution rate of 285.7 μmol g 1 h 1. As a contrast sample, Cu2MoS4 nanosheets needed more than 1 h to degrade the MO solution and a hydrogen evolution rate of 6.2 μmol g 1 h 1. This work has explicitly revealed the different potential and band gap structure of the {001} and {010} facet for layered Cu2MoS4 nanomaterials. Based on the preceding discussion, regulating the exposed highenergy facet of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials can not only directly influence the DOS near the Fermi level, the VBM and CBM position, but can also improve the activation of water molecules and dye molecules. In addition, the {001} facet of Cu2WS4 and {010} facet of Cu2MoS4 has demonstrated better photocatalytic performance from both experimental and theoretical aspects. Thus, more works should be carried out to further understand the appealing effects of facet on the photocatalytic performance of Cu2MX4 and further development of high-efficiency photocatalysts with more exposed active facet.

sections.heading: 4.3. Layer Effect
sections.text:
Recently, fabrication of ultrathin or single layered twodimensional (2D) crystals have attracted enormous research attention due to their unique electronic, physical, and chemical properties. Compared to their bulk counterparts, the ultrathin nanomaterials are more suitable for the next-generation electronic devices and other surface-sensitive applications. In addition, the ultrathin 2D materials have also shown an enhanced light conversion efficiency owing to their wide light absorption and fast charge separation.[17,85] Since Cu2MX4 nanomaterials are composed of the layer structure, it is possible for bulk Cu2MX4 nanomaterials to be exfoliated to single layer or ultrathin nanosheet. In addition, the solution-based exfoliation energy for I- and P-phase Cu2MoS4 has been simulated with the required energy ranging from 13 to 21meV Å 2, which is close to that of graphite andMoS2, indicating that the layered Cu2MX4 nanomaterials can be exfoliated by solution-based exfoliation

sections.heading: 4.4. Hybridization With Other Components
sections.text:
In order to enhance the charge transfer process and to prevent the recombination of photo-induced charges, developing new hybrids with compensated properties form individual functional components is a competitive approach, especially for improving the light conversion efficiency. As shown in Figure 5A,B, Cu2O@NiO@Cu2MoS4 ternary hybrids were fabricated for the photocathode toward hydrogen generation in water. In the hybridization, the Cu2O acted as the photo-captor and the Cu2MoS4 mainly contributed toward the hydrogen generation while the NiO interlayer enhanced the charge transfer from Cu2O to Cu2MoS4. Thus, the synergistic effect between the three components jointly enhanced the photoelectric light conversion efficiency with a photocurrent density of 1.25mAcm 2 (Figure 5C).[90]
Furthermore, the D-π-A organic dye-sensitized TiO2@Cu2WS4 photocatalytic system was recently fabricated for hydrogen evolution.[91] The hybrid has shown narrower band gap of 1.80 eV than that of TiO2 (3.2 eV), which is much more
Sol. RRL 2019, 1800320 1800320 (1
suitable for the photo-induced water splitting. Moreover, the Dπ-A organic dye-sensitized TiO2@Cu2WS4 exhibited enhanced photocatalytic hydrogen evolution rate of 943 μmol g 1 h 1, higher than that of other combination of these components. Here, the electrons migrated to the CB of Cu2WS4 after photoinduced electrons were transferred to the CB of TiO2, afterwards, water molecules were reduced and the hydrogen generation occurred (Figure 5D). Similarly, the mixed I-phase and P-phase Cu2MoS4 nanosheets were fabricated on the surface of CdS nanorods with a low weight percentage (Figure 5E).[92] The photoluminescence (PL) spectra collected under 380 nm confirmed a weaker emission band in CdS@Cu2MoS4 composite. Meanwhile, the transient photocurrent response revealed that the CdS@Cu2MoS4 composite exhibited a higher photocurrent response. It is suggested that the hybrid can hold quicker charge transformation and separation efficiency, thus preventing the recombination of photo-induced electrons and holes. The synergistic effect between Cu2MoS4 nanosheet and CdS nanorod largely contributed to the significantly improved photocatalytic performance and durability. Besides, boosted performance could also be realized by anchoring noble metals on the catalysts surface, for example, the hydrogen evolution rate has been increased for about 20 times of Cu2WS4 loading with Ru nanoparticles than that of Cu2WS4 nanosheets, [52] which might

Due to the high charge mobility and large surface area, numerous efforts have been made with an aim to improve the material characteristics for an ideal catalytic performance by compounding with graphene or other carbon-based nanomaterials. The Cu2MoS4 hollow spheres,
[64] nanosheets, and nanotubes composite with rGO[75,93] and carbon dots decorated Cu2MoS4 nanosheets
[94] have been successfully assembled. The unique properties of carbon@Cu2MX4 hybrids can be generally attributed to the following aspects: 1) the high electron mobility of carbon leads to the fast charge transfer process after photo-excitation, which can prevent the recombination of the photo-induced electron-hole pairs in the materials; 2) the photocatalytic system shows enhanced light absorption in the visible region after compounding with carbon, which can highly promote the light conversion efficiency; 3) carbon-based materials express a large theoretical surface area, indicating that it can offer more sites to absorb the molecules for the photocatalytic degradation of pollutant; 4) because of the fact that the particle and sheet like materials are very susceptible for aggregation toward the catalytic process, grasping into carbon framework can effectively avoid the aggregation of this materials and ultimately promotes the stability and lifetime of the photocatalysts. As mentioned earlier, the structural properties of Cu2MX4 or other parent materials can be regulated by fabricating new photocatalytic system. In this regards, the electron-hole separation, charge transfer and catalysts lifetime can be improved, which is beneficial for the further applications of this cost-effective and environmental-friendly photocatalytic system.
Inspired by previous studies, in fabricating Cu2MX4 nanomaterials for photocatalytic applications, more attention should be paid toward the synergistic effect regarding morphology, facet, layer, and hybridization. For example, regulating the band gap structure of photocatalysts, which can directly enhance the absorption of light, is a critical step in high-efficiency transformation of solar energy to chemical energy. Besides, more intense investigation about the key role of fast photo-induced electron-hole separation are needed as well. For various morphologies of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials, we can easily find that the Cu2MoS4 nanotubes have shown optimal performance, which can be ascribed to the higher exposed surface area and more exposed active facet. To this regard, regulating of the morphology could also make contribution to the facet effect. Furthermore, investigating the photocatalytic active facet of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials and utilizing the exposed highly-efficient facet hold a great significance for the photoelectric converting. Hybridization, which can noticeably enhance the synergistic effect between different components, also provides a clear approach for the photocatalytic performance of Cu2MX4 based nanomaterials. Thus in practice, harmonizing the main approaches mentioned above is highly appreciated for the rational design of photocatalytic applications, rather than sticking to one of the listed strategies.

5. Conclusions and Future Perspectives
In this review, we summarized the recent advances in the controllable synthesis and photocatalytic applications of layered Cu2MX4 nanomaterials. Figure 6 shows the synthesis routes, the correlation between various material aspects and photocatalytic performance of Cu2MX4, indicating a high potential for efficient photodegradation of organic pollutant, water splitting and other applications.[95,96]Asdiscussed,modulationsof synthesis routescan allow Cu2MX4 nanomaterials to exhibit various morphologies with different characteristics, thereby enabling efficient and durable photocatalysis. CombiningCu2MX4with other functionalmaterials (e.g., TiO2, g-C3N4, CdS, and carbon) can significantly improve the photocatalytic performance with the help of enhanced activity.
Despite this progressive works related to the Cu2MX4 nanomaterials, there are still some challenges in the way of their widespread applications:
1)
1 o
Although Cu2MoS4 and Cu2WS4 with various morphologies have been successfully synthesized through wet-chemical synthesis method, Cu2MoSe4 and Cu2WSe4 are rarely reported. Thus new synthetic methods and technologies should also be developed for controllably preparing Cu2MSe4 nanomaterials.
2) The current synthesis methods mostly focus on the wetchemical routes while the physical methods for single crystalline bulk materials with fewer defects (e.g., CVD and CVT) are still lacking. As is known to us all, single crystal with high quality and large size is critical to fabricate highperformance electric devices. Thus, it is highly desirable to develop new physical method for Cu2MX4 large sized single crystal, and open a window for further exploration of the unique electronic properties using field effect transistors. 3)
Considering layered structure of the Cu2MX4 nanomaterials, it is suitable to integrate Cu2MX4 layers with other 2D
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimf 13)
Sol.
materials to form unique hetrostructures, which can effectively enhance the photocatalytic activity under visiblelight region. However, large sizes of bulk materials with multi-layer extremely restrain their photocatalytic performance because of the recombination of photo-induced electrons and holes in the bulk materials and reduced exposure of active catalytic sites. Hence, more efforts are required on the exfoliation of Cu2MX4 to form monolayer or few layers for further verifying their photocatalytic performance.
4) To date, most of reports related to Cu2MX4 are focused on the photocatalytic hydrogen generation and photodegradation of organic pollutant. The progress on the degradation of solidphase pollutants, air cleaning, and new photocatalytic technologies such as CO2 photoreduction and N2 photoreduction is still lacking. 5)
For the large-scale generalization of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials in photocatalysis, the photocatalytic system with suitable morphology, facet and high-efficiency hybridization component should be considered integrally. Thereby, promoting the photocatalytic performance from the view point of regulating the band gap structure, fast charge transfer and the interfacial interaction between different components.
All in all, achieving high performance toward photocatalytic applications by the rational design and controllable synthesis of ternary Cu2MX4 is still the greatest challenging in this field of research. In combination with the advanced characterization tools, we hope various approaches used to control microstructure and electronic structures can open an efficient way for future exploration of Cu2MX4 potential applications in photocatalysis and other related fields.

metadata.abstractText: Photocatalytic technologies, based on efficient light absorption and conversion, have emerged as a viable solution to overcome the problems related to energy and the environment. Development of new cost-effective materials coupled with the green synthesis routes in order to replace the noble metalbased catalysts is critical to overcoming this challenge. In this review, a brief summary of the recent progress in ternary layered Cu2MX4 (M1⁄4Mo, W; X1⁄4 S, Se) nanomaterials and their photocatalytic performance is presented. First, the structural configurations with different phases and crystallinity are described, as well as various experimental synthesis methods of Cu2MX4 nanomaterials. Thereafter, the effect of morphology modulation, facet selection, and multicomponent hybridization on the catalytic activity of Cu2MX4 is elucidated. In addition, a proposal for highly-efficient Cu2MX4 photocatalysts is presented via rational designing strategies for realizing their specific applications in the fields of photodegradating organic pollutants, water splitting, and other photocatalytic reactions. Finally, the existing research challenges related to ternary Cu2MX4 layers along with future prospects are discussed in detail.
